channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Begins Striking ISIS in Iraq, Trying to Reclaim Tikrit
item.description: American warplanes began airstrikes against Islamic State positions in the Iraqi city, aiding a three-week offensive by a coalition of Shiite militias and Iraqi security forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and PETER BAKER

item.title: Cost a Factor in Streaming Flight Data in Real Time
item.description: Another plane crash has many in aviation asking whether commercial flights should be required to transmit live data in real time.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: A black box recovered from the Germanwings Airbus A320 that crashed Tuesday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Begins Air Assault in Yemen
item.description: Saudi Arabia launched airstrikes with a coalition of 10 nations. The strikes came as Yemen was hurtling toward civil war after months of turmoil.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Anti-Houthi protesters carried a fellow demonstrator after police troopers opened fire to disperse them in Taiz on Wednesday.

item.title: Netanyahu Told to Mend Ties With Washington
item.description: In handing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the task of forming a new government, Israel’s president chided him for warning that Arab citizens were flocking to polling places in “droves.”
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Israel’s president, Reuven Rivlin, on Thursday.

item.title: Memo From Washington: Ghani Addresses Congress, Eager to Rebuild Afghan-U.S. Ties
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, addressing a joint meeting of Congress, said he wanted to repair a partnership that had frayed badly.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Yehuda Avner, Diplomat and Aide to Israeli Leaders, Dies at 86
item.description: Mr. Avner was an adviser and speechwriter to Israel’s leaders for some three decades, and also served as Israel’s ambassador to Britain and Australia.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Yehuda Avner and his wife Mimi, in London on Aug. 3, 1983.

item.title: Germanwings Pilot Was Locked Out of Cockpit Before Crash in France
item.description: As officials struggled to explain why a jet with 150 people on board crashed, an investigator said evidence indicated that one pilot left the cockpit and was unable to get back in.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A French rescue worker on Wednesday near the crash site of a Germanwings jet.

item.title: Matter: In Iceland’s DNA, New Clues to Disease-Causing Genes
item.description: The results uncovered a host of previously unknown gene mutations that may play roles in ailments as diverse as Alzheimer’s disease, heart disease and gallstones.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER
item.media:description: Blood samples used by Decode for genetics research.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, Supporters of Detained Feminists Come Under Pressure
item.description: Students who signed petitions calling for the release of the women say they have been warned that their prospects for further education and jobs could be affected.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators in front of the Central Government Liaison Office in Hong Kong last Saturday call on Beijing to release the five women detained as they were planning to distribute stickers highlighting the problem of sexual harassment on public transport.

item.title: Army Apologizes for Treatment of Veterans Exposed to Chemical Weapons in Iraq
item.description: The Army under secretary, Brad R. Carson, said that those suffering from exposure to the weapons would be accounted for and offered medical screening.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: was injured by a mustard agent in March 2007.

item.title: Egyptian Woman Reveals 42-Year Secret of Survival: Pretending to Be a Man
item.description: For Sisa Abu Daooh, what began as a way to survive rural poverty evolved into her preferred way of life and a means of navigating a world dominated by men.
item.dc:creator: JARED MALSIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: For 42 years, Sisa Abu Daooh has been dressing as a man to escape restrictions on women’s employment and earn enough to support her daughter.

item.title: Challenges Weigh Heavily on Recovery Efforts in Germanwings Crash
item.description: The crash site is inaccessible by road or even foot, making helicopter flights the only way in, and most of the area is covered by steep hillside.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Recovery workers prepared Wednesday to return to the crash site near Seyne-les-Alpes, France.

item.title: Ukraine Arrests 2 Officials as Nation Watches on TV
item.description: The director of the emergency services ministry and his deputy were handcuffed at a meeting and face charges of embezzlement and abuse of power.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: World Briefing: Italian Court Postpones Ruling in Amanda Knox Case
item.description: A hearing on whether the court should uphold the murder convictions of Ms. Knox and her Italian former boyfriend went slowly, forcing the judges to postpone a decision until Friday.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Pakistani Army Begins Offensive to Drive Militants From Tirah Valley
item.description: Dozens of pro-Taliban militants and at least 16 soldiers have died in fighting in the Tirah Valley, on the border with Afghanistan, officials said.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: World Briefing: Polish Ex-Priest Sentenced to 7 Years on Abuse Charges
item.description: The former priest, Wojciech Gil, was charged with sexually abusing eight children in Poland and the Dominican Republic.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: German Town in Shock After Loss of 16 Students and 2 Teachers in Jet Crash
item.description: Officials in Haltern Am See, Germany, a community of 38,000 people, said they had been inundated with condolence messages from around the world after word that a group of 10th graders traveling with two teachers were among the dead.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Students at a memorial on the steps of Joseph-König-Gymnasium on Wednesday in Haltern am See, Germany. Sixteen students and two teachers died in the Germanwings plane crash.

item.title: Court Blocks Jihadist Website Used to Recruit Turks to Islamic State
item.description: The court said that the website, Takva Haber, and its affiliate video site, Takva Tube, were spreading “terror propaganda.”
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Jeremy Clarkson Loses Contract as Host of BBC’s ‘Top Gear’
item.description: The BBC said it would not renew the contract of the host of the popular car-based TV show, who was suspended after a “fracas” with a producer.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: The “Top Gear” host Jeremy Clarkson outside his home in London on Tuesday. The BBC announced on Wednesday that Mr. Clarkson's contract would not be renewed.

item.title: Dozens Arrested in Raids to Stem Illegal Influx of Kosovars
item.description: The European authorities arrested 77 people accused of running a network smuggling in immigrants from Kosovo to countries in Western Europe.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
